title: 110_s1965
content:
The "Protecting Children in the 21st Century Act" includes provisions for promoting a safe internet for children and enhancing child pornography enforcement. It covers internet safety, public awareness campaigns, annual reports, online safety in schools, and definitions. TITLE I--PROMOTING A SAFE INTERNET FOR CHILDREN

SEC. 101. INTERNET SAFETY. The issue of Internet safety includes promoting safe online activity for children, protecting them from cybercrimes, and helping parents shield them from inappropriate material.

SEC. 102. PUBLIC AWARENESS CAMPAIGN. The Federal Trade Commission will implement a nationwide program to raise public awareness and educate on promoting safe Internet use for children. This program will involve various entities in identifying best practices, conducting outreach campaigns, and sharing up-to-date information on Internet safety. The Federal Trade Commission will implement a nationwide program to raise public awareness and educate on promoting safe Internet use for children by facilitating access to Internet safety education and public awareness efforts through various entities. The Commission must submit an annual report to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation detailing its activities from the previous year. Additionally, there is a provision for the establishment of an Online Safety and Technology Working Group. Within 90 days of enactment, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce will establish an Online Safety and Technology working group to review industry efforts promoting online safety for children and reporting child pornography. The Online Safety and Technology working group will review industry efforts promoting online safety for children, reporting child pornography, record retention practices of service providers, and technologies to protect children from inappropriate internet content. Within 1 year, a report will be submitted detailing findings on the effectiveness of strategies and technologies. The working group will review industry efforts promoting online safety for children, including parental control technologies and incentives to increase effectiveness. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the working group. SEC. 105 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include educating minors about appropriate online behavior, interacting on social networking websites, chat rooms, and cyberbullying awareness. SEC. 106 defines terms such as "Commission" as the Federal Trade Commission and "Internet" as the interconnected network of computer and telecommunications facilities. TITLE II focuses on enhancing child pornography enforcement, including prevention and forfeitures related to violations. The Communications Act of 1934 was amended to include violations of section 227 of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990. This amendment was passed by the Senate on May 22, 2008. To protect children from cybercrimes, including online predators and child pornography, and help parents shield minors from inappropriate material.
